page.title: 01Maltby and District
page.content: The Maltby district is a gentle dip slope of Magnesian limestone,forming part of the concealed coalfield of South Yorkshire. The coal measures are deep down and hidden by the newer cover of limestone. Whilst the exposed coalfield further west became industrialised our area remained rural and agricultural. Up to 1910 the area contained one village,one hamlet and a few scattered farms. The coming of a branch railway and the sinking of the colliery in the early 20th century signalled the transformation of the area. The development of a major colliery has had a profound impact upon employment and the environment,and created multiplier effects for secondary and tertiary industries so that Maltby is an expanding small town with a variety of functions.
